Fields.DialogueText: When ever am I not, Capitaine?
@BATTLE
Out with it. I know you know about this.
Take a compliment when it's given, Surcouf. Nothing goes missing aboard you. You always make sure of that.
We're out of soap already?
I... I'm afraid I don't understand it, Captain. The emergency resupply was just last Thursday...
Well, it won't kill us, but it'll certainly be an unpleasant few days.
What good fortune that I do not sweat.
I know for a fact that isn't true.
Just how closely do you pay attention to the question of whether I sweat, Capitaine?
Surcouf, I don't--
I'll just, um... see myself out, then?

Fields.MenuText: You're going to get me court-martialed one of these days.

Fields.DialogueText: You leave the little problems to me, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Well, as long as you've started the rumor, you might as well tell me whether you sweat.
Shameless as ever.

Fields.DialogueText: How easily your principles sway, Capitaine! You must be listening to me after all.
Shame is for those who cannot buy dignity.
Did you come across some proof during our resupply?
A word from the wise, Capitaine. Make sure your lies are less dangerous than the truth.
Hmm.
Something on your mind?
To contradict you is to plead incompetence. To agree is to admit fault.
Capitaine, I do believe you have finally managed to trap me!
Ah, the risks I take, admitting a partner in crime... to be strung up on my own meticulous gallows!
A confession? Now I know you're up to something.
Hiding in plain sight, eh?
It works for the Morganas, does it not?
Work over there, won't you? You're fouling up my air.
Whose fault is that? I don't know! Nobody asked for your complaints!
Aha! The sale is over, everyone! It appears some Morganas do not appreciate honest business!
@BATTLE
What the hell good would that do? You smell worse than the diesel!
Look who's got a sensitive nose! You bruise it sticking it into people's business?
I'll give you a bruised nose, you lousy--
Calmez-vous, gentlemen! I have the solution you seek.
That scent... Soap!?
Where'd you get it? Give it here!
Ah! Patience, mon ami. I do not simply hand these things out. For merely ten centimes, a whole bar can be--
Charging for basic hygiene? What kind of gouger are you?
A wise investment!
The hell with it. I'll take one. If it does anything at all about your stench, I'll make it last the year!
I think I'll crack this one open right...
Whoa! There's five francs wrapped around it!
What!? Give that here!
Maybe you should get your own! Goodness knows you could use some.
Maybe I should! I'll take two!
*CLAMORING*
Now, now, there's enough for everyone! But only just enough!

Fields.MenuText: It's against my better judgment... but it's getting unbearable here.

Fields.DialogueText: Magnifique! I have saved this bar especially for you.
Surcouf, this is low even for you.

Fields.MenuText: Before the price hike, you mean.
Don't mind me. Just tallying up the crimes.

Fields.DialogueText: Such a business-savvy capitaine you are!
Volunteering to be my biographer? How kind, Capitaine!
Ah, Capitaine! Come get them while they are hot!
Aw, hell, it's just soap.
Ha! Two francs in this one!
I saw you talking to that five-franc sailor earlier, you know.
To think the loyalty of men is worth so little.
For you, my company is free.

Fields.MenuText: Everyone has a price.

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE
You look lonely here in the mess, Capitaine. Join me in some coffee?
How much?

Fields.MenuText: Sure. Maybe I'll find a franc at the bottom of my cup.
Charity looks good on you.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, to afford to throw them around...
We all have outfits we save for special occasions.
And here is the coffee. Santé.
Oui, and I will extract yours when the time comes.
Surcouf, that coffee's boiling!
Sharpens the senses.
*GULP*
*CRUNCH*
What did that mug ever do to you?
Capitaine, je suis ruinée!
I might have guessed it was about the contraband.
Millions in a dozen currencies... treasures from five continents... all of it, rotting at the bottom of the sea! And for what? Some routine search?
How much debt are you in, exactly?
Five... *sob* hundred...
Well, that's not so--
... thousand... *sob*
Half a million francs!? You didn't see fit to tell me about this?
There are many things I do not see fit to tell you, Capitaine! Trade secrets do not keep themselves!
And here I sit, my trade's greatest practitioner... reduced to soap scams to rebuild my fortune!
What about your bank accounts?
Drained, after that accursed inspection. I had to settle up with my contacts. Would that you had scuttled me instead...
Hey now, none of that. Maybe you can turn over a new leaf. Go legitimate.
Are you in a fighting mood?
Face me, Morganas! Tremble before the desperate hatred poverty has wrought within my soul!
I am not in a joking mood, Capitaine!
At least she's motivated.
Neuf cent mille quatre-vingt-huit, neuf cent mille quatre-vingt-neuf...
Almost ready, Surcouf?
Never you fear, Capitaine. I shall tell you all about it once we've cleared ourselves a path!
@BATTLE
Ah, Capitaine, I have been ready. This is my third count of the merchandise.
You mean contraband.
Toujours. I have to finish recouping our losses somehow.

Fields.MenuText: "Our" losses?

Fields.DialogueText: And our gains, naturellement. I've cut you in on ten percent of the proceeds.
I suppose crime does pay.

Fields.MenuText: Going legitimate isn't in the cards?
You didn't plan for losing everything?

Fields.DialogueText: Not for the sums I deal in.
My rainy day fund wasn't prepared for a hurricane.
Generous.
You ensured the crew's cooperation, after all. I can't just forge your name without giving something in return.
After my finances recover, that is.
If it were so simple, everyone would do it.
More than anything. But it can cost a great deal, too.
You'd like that, wouldn't you? A world where everyone's as dishonest as you are?
Bien sûr que non! Scruples are essential to a polite society.
We less polite folk need something to blend into, after all.
So what are we smuggling this time? Something less poisonous than puffer fish, ideally?
Ah, there is our business partner now!
While we're learning things, what exactly are we transporting?
Just once I'd like to not worry that my own Belle is going to get me blown up.
All right, we've begun our standard deviation from the formation.
So I've noticed. Say, when do we meet your "business associates" on this patrol of yours?
What fortune to have a proactive Morgana killer in me, Capitaine! A keen eye for enemy movement just beyond our patrol routes...
If there is one thing we Belles know about Morganas, it is that they are always adapting to our tactics. Outlaws: ever the consummate students.
Incisive as ever, Capitaine, but you must not let some foolhardy hunt for hypocrisy satisfy you.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. It's too easy.

Fields.DialogueText: Set small goals and you will win small victories in large shadows.

Fields.MenuText: Nor my share of the spoils. You can do better than ten percent.
Maybe it's just my overdeveloped sense of justice.

Fields.DialogueText: Ten percent and a pat on the head for good behavior, then.
Très probablement. I will wear you down eventually.
So it's back to the usual smuggling.
Did those big guys in port with all the scars and tattoos tell you that?
I am merely a humble intermediary, Capitaine! It is no different than borrowing a cup of sugar for your next-door neighbor.
In surprisingly soft voices. Consider this a cost of doing business with the INPF.
That's one way to describe breaking maritime law.
You see? I am doing wonders for your vocabulary!
Sugar, actually.
Not the worst thing we could be trafficking.
And excellent padding for explosive shells.
And there they are! How elegantly everything falls into place.
Steady on, Surcouf. We want to be alive to do your dirty work...
@BATTLE
Ah, thrilling as ever!
Worry not, Capitaine. I am still convinced you are irreplaceable.
And off they go!
With illicit ordnance bound for goodness knows where.
Does it not spark your imagination? A historic city, holding out against the tide of darkness, suddenly blessed with a windfall in steel and powder...

Fields.MenuText: They're going to need it. There's more at stake here than just your pocketbook.
I'm actively trying not to think about where it could be going.
I'm more concerned with the crew's silence.

Fields.DialogueText: There are a great many things at stake in this war, Capitaine. Our part in this begins and ends with a briefcase full of cash.
Far from us and our problems.
At least you got half up front.
Do not worry, Capitaine. I employ only the most trustworthy crew to handle my merchandise.
By which you mean the most easily blackmailed.
I admit I have a nose for gambling debts.
With the other half payable in port. I would have pushed for sixty percent, but these are new business partners.
Got to build up a professional relationship before you can really fleece someone.
It's one thing to take what you can get from someone you'll never see again. Quite another to become indispensable. Golden geese and all that.
At least we've reached an--
What the hell?
Merde! Capitaine, our partners!
@BATTLE
Veracruz. Mexico's invested so much in their quarantine, and even the underworld must do its part for the war effort.
So you say.
Surrounded. It seems we--
Surcouf, that's right through a burning vessel!
@BATTLE
How's it looking, Surcouf?
Là bas! An opening!
That of our business partners. None remain alive to complain. Trust me.
Trust you?
They did not. Look where it got them.
That's not remotely the same--
Torpedo! We shatter the hulk and retreat through it!
I'm going to have a merry time explaining this to Command.
Then perhaps you should allow me.

Fields.MenuText: We're going to be in enough trouble without lies digging us deeper.
Go for it. I've got enough on my plate trying to write this up cleanly.
Whatever you're planning to tell them, keep me out of it.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, you know as well as I do that the truth will not set me free.
You?
Us.
And again, there were no survivors?
The capitaine is best that capitaines least!
Even if we needed a scapegoat, there are at least a dozen goats I'd scape before you.
Aucun survivant. I'm afraid our contraband ammunition destroyed them utterly.
Well, their contraband ammunition. We were simply intermediaries.
Who led civilians straight into a war zone!
Civilians engaged in smuggling of dangerous weaponry. Sailors of ill repute and worse morals. Pirates, really. We're better off without them.
Takes one to know one.
Why, I see no pirates skulking around this vessel. Do you?
No, you tend to saunter.
You ought to try it sometime.
Piracy?
Sauntering. It does wonders for stress.
... I'm going to draft a very, very long letter to the INPF about collateral damage protocol. Just for the sake of argument.
Care for a glass, Capitaine?
Wine at this hour?
Our enemies make no such distinctions. Neither should our friends.
Least of all those hailing from Nantes and bottled in 1936.

Fields.MenuText: Why not? One won't kill me.

Fields.DialogueText: There is the Capitaine I know and approve of. Always willing to fight and relax at the Belle's side.

Fields.MenuText: Is this where you poison me and take control of the ship?
It'll have to wait. I need to finish this weapon requisition form.

Fields.DialogueText: Who would write to Command for new toys? Moi? It would be a conflict of interests.
A present? Capitaine, you shouldn't have!
You know, I thought you'd steer clear of drinking after that moonshine explosion.
We made a compelling case in our after action report on the ambush.
Bien sûr. Business is much easier to conduct under arms.
Not in so many words, but I made a similar point.
Your favorite kind of conflict.
Oui, but a noisy one.
For a while, so did I. But time heals all wounds. And time is money, of course, so by the transitive property--
You just can't resist a big score, can you?
Non, but this is not the point. The point is that I have done my grieving, and now it is time we took action.
What do you call that arms deal gone wrong? Didn't you sink half a million into it?
More, in fact, now that I run the numbers. But if you owe the bank pocket change, that is your problem.
If you owe the bank millions... well, that is the bank's problem.
Every time I think you've hit rock bottom, you find some way to keep digging.
More fool you for putting the ladder down after me.
My point being, I have convinced my benefactors that all I need is time to double their investment in me.
With a local economy your unwitting investors.
Regional, actually.
I can't decide whether I want to know more about what you're doing or less.
One crisis at a time, Capitaine. Let us give ourselves some room to breathe.
@BATTLE
Now, help me with it. It's my last bottle and I save it for occasions when all seems lost.
Ah, to be flush once more with money...
Other people's money.
The very best kind! Now, first things first--
We stick to the routine patrol.
Pardon?
You heard me. We don't exactly have a good track record for your one-woman jaunts lately.
Perhaps my contacts do not.
We're not the only ones who saw the wreck, you know.
An unfortunate civilian vessel where it ought not to have been, oui.
Which we failed to save.
Must we save every human on our way to saving humanity?

Fields.MenuText: Your human captain insists we try.
The company you keep has me asking that question sometimes.
I'm going to pretend I didn't hear that.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, oui, oui. You have pride of place on my list.
My contacts are exactly as honorable as I need them to be!
I do love it when you talk that way.
Look, you can run guns or you can fight Morganas. It's getting harder to do both at the same time.
Hmm. There is calculated risk, and then there is recklessness.
And then there is gross recklessness.
Let's split hairs in a different direction. From now on, we stick close to the rest of the formation. We can't be planning your business around the Morganas.
... Perhaps you are right, Capitaine. I will think on this.
With what wine?
For now, let us toast our impending victory!
My first purchase with my new bank loan. The cost is a pittance compared to what we stand to gain!
Thank goodness you're not my accountant.
Not on paper.
@BATTLE
Don't lose sleep over it. That's what I'm here for.
@BATTLE
Is that everything?
Yes, Captain. And I double-checked the soap.
Good. We're not going through that kind of nonsense again.
Right.
Say, you and the Belle...

Fields.MenuText: What about us?

Fields.DialogueText: Is there anything... going on between you?

Fields.MenuText: Have a strictly professional relationship. Nothing more.
Who have you been talking to?

Fields.DialogueText: One of Surcouf's away team. He was of the opinion that you two were engaging in... relations.
I'm even less her type than she is mine.
Of course, Captain. I thought--
Out of my way!
Damn it, I saw it first!
Salvage law, jackass! I *grabbed* it first!
I'll salvage you, you--
This may be as good a time as any to address the culture I'm worried Surcouf is fostering among the crew.
She's on top of it.
That's the crux of my concern, actually. Piracy... well, it isn't a good look. Even if we pick good targets.
Yes, Captain.
Ah, look at them run. It gives one such hope for the future, no?
Let's clear out these Morganas so we have a future.
I've read Homer too. Dismissed.
The blade itself incites to--
C'est vrai. Breakfast is the most important meal of the day.
Not that. And not until you tell me how much of that bank loan you've spent.
@BATTLE
Aren't you taking all this a little less seriously than you should?
Pass me that charcuterie board again.
Easy on those purse strings, Capitaine, you're going to wear grooves in your fingers.
It's my head I'm worried about. The INPF doesn't make policy of your shopping sprees.
I am merely... what is it the Soviet girls say? Developing the means of production.
This isn't like you, Surcouf. You plan for everything.

Fields.MenuText: By dining on wine and fine cheese.

Fields.DialogueText: One cannot conduct high finance on an empty stomach.

Fields.MenuText: Don't dress it up. This is like stealing from thousands of people at once.
I don't think the New Economic Policy revolved around smuggling and embezzlement.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I do love it when you talk dirty to me.
You've read economics, Capitaine. They are merely positive externalities.
Oui.
So what happens when the crew realize you're bankrupt?
The crew that you're purportedly paying off to keep quiet about your activities?
Madame Surcouf? I got that salvage manifest you wanted.
Ah, formidable! My, the things the Morganas leave littering the harbors.
About my fee--
Oui, oui, oui. Take twelve off the top when you find it a good home.
Thank you kindly!
An advance, eh?
My ventures are many and varied. He'll take fifteen and count on me looking the other way.
In any event, a few immediate finder's fees should come to less than the sum I'd promised him at the end of his tour. Time is money, indeed.
That answers one question, at least. Upgrade your underlings to accomplices and they won't mind a little fleecing.
They had better not. I have seven other banks to repay with their findings.
More venison, Capitaine?
I think I'm going to need it.
Awfully confident.
It is what I would do.
Hmm... south by southwest at 190, and...
This might be the first time I've caught you in the act.
I was hoping to meet you there, Capitaine!
At my securely locked desk.
Locked, oui. We are allies. Why should we have secrets from each other?

Fields.MenuText: You're kidding, right?
Professional courtesy?
You don't want to know everything I've got to hide.

Fields.DialogueText: And you thought you'd never understand my humor!
What is courteous about deception, Capitaine?
Nor do I particularly care. It is not in me to question my sources of income.
Wait, that's a chart of the--
Hmm. The Capitaine really is getting better at hiding the jelly beans.
Caribbean, oui. I thought I'd do some research.
Feel free to sift through those recent reports from Command. Relevant pieces underlined.
Hmm. These coordinates... say, they're all in the Bay of Campeche.
And getting closer to Veracruz as we speak. My working theory is that the Morganas smell blood in the water.
... You're talking about the weapon shipment.
Oui.
Your weapon shipment.
If you would like to call it that.
The one that the Morganas blew up.
This is one factor in that city's vulnerable condition, oui.
@BATTLE
All right, I think we've found our next objective.
How regrettable that they did not get the shipment of explosive shells they wanted, non?
And I suppose those manifests and dock schematics are for purely strategic purposes.
Now, now. Are we going to stand around and wring our hands or are we going to sail gallantly to victory?
You can leave all that where it is. We can plan later.
*Thoroughly.*
Oui, oui, oui. Expect me on the bridge inside of three minutes.
Bien sûr que non. I--

Fields.MenuText: French?

Fields.DialogueText: Surcouf, no.
I want you to get out of the red, but I can't countenance stealing from a city we've signed up to defend.
Surcouf, oui.
Ah, Capitaine, Capitaine. Again and again I give you an opportunity to speak my language and again and again you spurn me.
Damn it, I know you're not the one doing the stealing. It's a distinction without a difference when the crew's on your payroll.

Fields.MenuText: How should I describe it, then? An "investment?"
I guess you don't find out about the best opportunities until it's too late.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be obtuse. It's unbecoming.
You're asking me to aid and abet looting.
Ah, so you simply choose not to.
Such is the freewheeling life of a corsaire.
Avarice has been sighted with the Morgana forces approaching Veracruz. Several of her, in fact.
The Mexicans will expect things to go missing here and there. Including some gold bound for the INPF's Caribbean headquarters.
I was not born a thief, Capitaine, just as you were not born a capitaine.
But where would we be if I went around in a thief uniform wearing a thief hat and asking people to call me "Thief?"
Non, much better to speak of these things in a language we can all understand. You must get used to operating under scrutiny.
So that's what this is all about. And how do you expect to sell several tons of hot gold, let alone move it?
Oh, I don't. While the port authority jealously guards it, our dutiful salvage team will secure our true quarry.
Is that what we're calling it now?
Whatever do you mean?
If you have to hide one heist with another, I can't help but think not all of their salvage is underwater.
You are learning our argot after all, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
... Fine. One big score and then we're laying low, to put it your way. What do you need from me?
Simply to look the other way.
Look at it this way if you really must. What sort of asset will I be if I am repossessed?
Sept cent soixante et un... et la produit...
Now would be a good time to fire back, Surcouf!
@BATTLE
Oui, oui, oui! I am simply getting inside her range.
We're inside her range, all right. You can save the accounting for later.
And not a moment too soon! There is the signal from the shore.
Finally.
A police whistle?
Appropriated for a higher purpose, and far from the scene of the salvage.

Fields.MenuText: You plan for everything, don't you?
I suppose I should be happy you don't bribe the police.
You don't think anyone will notice?

Fields.DialogueText: "Didn't."
Not with the water still steaming.  By the time it all dies down, my people will be long gone.
Versatility can often look like preparation. It comes with experience.
So how long are we supposed to lend out crew to your adventures?
The rendezvous point is just up the coast. If I am right - and I am always right - I will have enough to pay off my creditors and be...
... Eight hundred francs richer.
Heh. All that for a couple of very fancy dinners, eh?
They will be the most delectable I have ever tasted, Capitaine. The first step toward freedom is in many ways the sweetest.
You never know when you will take the last. But the first is one thing that can never be stolen from you.
Imagine how much sooner you could have taken that last step if you'd passed on the charcuterie.
Even in bondage, a submarine deserves nice things.
Well, that's the hard part down. Now we wait.
The fun part, en vérité. Now we are in for the boring, lonely part of the heist.
Non, which one? New York? London?
Hindustan, actually.
Letter for you, Surcouf. It's the Times this time.
I really ought to have a template for these things. Doesn't Mademoiselle Hood do that? She's always in the papers.
You can case a port, Capitaine. Not an international media circus!
Well, congratulations, Surcouf. You've stolen your way into heroism.

Fields.MenuText: This from the Belle who makes a habit of operating in plain sight.
How do you think I feel? I have enough to deal with without fending off this fawning.
I'll say. Someone might find out where all their tobacco went.

Fields.DialogueText: You will get used to the adulation, Capitaine. Think of it as your due.
Into the lungs of a thousand satisfied customers, naturellement... if by a different merchant.
I doubt anyone plans for worldwide media coverage.
Because it is a walking prison, Capitaine. The last thing I need is all eyes on me.
Given our performance at Veracruz, we're being given first priority for the Panama Canal patrol.
Conspicuously in the opposite direction of our rendezvous.
And on a strict timetable. Remind me of the interest rate on your loan?
Criminal, Capitaine, and *that* is saying something.
How's that goal of emancipating yourself coming?
No more quickly with your mockery.
But I take your point. It seems that in escaping one master, I have courted another.
And here come a few more to audition for the job.
Don't get me wrong, Surcouf. I'm on your side.
I have certainly invested enough to keep you here.
That "last, best hope" you mentioned once? You don't get it from someone who doesn't believe in you.
Just... believe in me when I try and give it to you, okay?
*sigh*
As ever, the only way out is through.
@BATTLE
Restrictions, restrictions.
They're not taking chances with their quarantine.
That was the Panamanian port authority. We're cleared to depart.
Nor should they, Capitaine. What with the Sloth incident, they are right to sense Morgana hands in this.
But it is doing nothing for my restlessness.

Fields.MenuText: You'll find something to steal.
Whatever they're dealing with, I'm just glad it hasn't reached Veracruz.
You haven't stopped pacing since we entered port. One of our guys says his quarters are vibrating.

Fields.DialogueText: It is difficult not to.
It is hard enough to rebuild oneself without mysterious illnesses complicating things.
He'll learn to like it.
Frozen in a pool of necessity... All eyes upon my every move...
Why, there is nothing for it but to sit here and reminisce on past glorious enterprises.
Crimes.
Oh, drink your wine.
Shouldn't you be... I don't know, living within your means? Given your inability to contact your accomplices, that is.
My means are only as limited as my methods, Capitaine. And my *partners* are resourceful sorts. They will be following my movements and moving in kind.
Assuming they don't get arrested first.
You think so little of your crew?
They've learned it by watching you. Just the same way I noticed you pickpocketing me when you greeted me.
Even my sleight of hand is atrophying! Oh, Capitaine, save me from this... this cabin fever!
Wish granted. We've got Morganas.
Quite the quarantine you humans have going.
It's not to keep them out. It's to keep us in.
And give me back my wallet.
@BATTLE
You will thank me later!
Morganas, too... ugh. One problem at a time.
@BATTLE
All right, mail time... Surcouf, Surcouf, supply officer, me, Surcouf again...
What the hell? This package weighs a ton...
Capitaine, put that down at once!
Surcouf? What are you--
*BOOM*
What the--
A mail bomb?
Thank goodness I was tidying your quarters when I was, Capitaine. If you had opened that... why, I fear the war would have turned on it.

Fields.MenuText: "Tidying."
Who would have sent it?
What did you do with it?

Fields.DialogueText: I can scarcely tell which of your drawers is your junk drawer, being candid.
As a matter of fact, I am diving now to the bottom of this mystery.
Would that I could have thrown the thing at a Morgana. Non, Capitaine, I opted for a controlled demolition.
I-- Never mind. We've got a bomb to consider.
I thought your gloves looked singed.
Some head will roll for it in time. For observe, Capitaine - I have found a clue to our culprit.
Shrapnel?
I recognize the markings, Capitaine. This bomb was converted from an explosive shell. Does this begin to sound familiar?
That's impossible. Your shipment went up in flames.
This is not the merchandise, Capitaine.
Contraband.
Capitaine, the next thing I steal will be your tongue from your head.
As I was saying. It is a shell of the type we were transporting.
All the better to keep me quiet.
So it isn't just a bomb. It's a message. Someone knows what you were up to.
And has a disappointing lack of faith in our powers of deduction. There was a letter pinned to the side of the package explaining everything.
Let me see that.
... Damn. It's burned away right where the signature would be.
It was like that when I found it, Capitaine. Our bomber has a flair for the mysterious... and on the grave of my namesake, I swear it will be the end of them.
Hmm... survivor of the smuggler crew, threats of vengeance, taunts, vague clues...
I already have, Capitaine. This line about a "royal port" is unmistakable.
That's our patrol route so far. And Kingston is the first port of call since the bombing. It proves that someone's tracking us.
All right, here we are in Kingston. Check the letter.
We're positive?
As positive as we were about the "princely city," the "true cross," and the "blue bridge." These riddles were written to be solved.
Or that someone is informing on us.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we should be looking among your accomplices.
We'll let Command take care of it. This is a crime against the French navy and the INPF.
Someone among the crew?

Fields.DialogueText: I forgive your suspicion, but this does not explain the bomber's prediction of our current assignment.
Bonne chance, with any evidence rotting at the bottom of the Bay of Campeche.
Improbable. I frisk them and search their quarters thoroughly after we put ashore.
How the hell did this get into the mail in the first place?
... All of them?
The price of liberty is eternal vigilance.
More to the point, how did you pick it out so quickly?
The way you struggled to lift it, what could it have been but something nefarious?
... And if it hadn't been a bomb?
You never get packages like that, Capitaine. Call it an educated guess.
Chronic unpopularity to the rescue.
Au contraire, Capitaine! The crew have told me they admire your permissive nature.
You know, the way you give compliments is remarkably similar to the way our bomber writes riddles.
Such are the ways of those who act with purpose.
Well, what's theirs?
They claim to have left another letter in a postbox near the port. I have sent one of our most fearless crew to collect it.
Surcouf, it could be anything!
He volunteered. Who am I to say no?
A thief with potentially one less loose end to tie up?
When have I ever denied it?
Whatever you're walking into, we don't have time for it.
There is never enough time, Capitaine. The days you have left don't have to be all bad.
@BATTLE
I make it my business not to know, Capitaine. I speak to my business partners, not their overlords.
As bad a time as this may seem to say I told you so...
Fine, fine. Let's see...
Neither does contact poison. Put them on and read.
Surcouf, your gloves don't fit me.
"The ordnance shipment was never intended for Veracruz. Our new mistresses will not be denied another."
"Glory to Avarice. Glory to the Morganas."
"Furnish a replacement within the fortnight or your crimes will be exposed to your leaders."
Some instructions and further boasting follow, and then...
Well.

Fields.MenuText: Did you know about this?
Do we buy this?
Who would be crazy enough to throw in with the Morganas?

Fields.DialogueText: Given the writer's insider knowledge, I do not think we can afford not to.
Who indeed? We Belles are almost universally better company.
Non, Capitaine, you cannot possibly blame me for this!
Surcouf, I've tolerated your activities up to a point. But running guns to anyone with a few francs to spare is--
What would you have me do, Capitaine? Go to my grave like those built before me?
Now, hold on. There's making money and then there's siphoning arms somewhere totally unaccountable.
What do you call the INPF lend-lease, Capitaine? French arms on German vessels? Italian guns in British hands?
Your hostilities will not disappear with the Morganas. You fuel a future threat to stave off the present one.
When humans do it, it is pragmatic. When Belles do it, it is treason?
Don't put words in our mouths. You could have directly armed Morganas!
Someone should have told the Morganas that before they ruined my business dealings!
Non, we have a letter from a knowledgeable individual who claims to speak for them.
Morgana infighting is nothing new. We have a letter that says at least one of them has us over a barrel.
Take it from a professional liar.
If they are lying, the Morganas will not simply back them up. That is a more dangerous bluff than any truth he could tell.
Let's put your other skills to use. This isn't over.
Nothing ever is, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Bon. Two weeks to deliver ourselves into the hands of the Morganas... or the authorities.
I thought your charcuterie board seemed remarkably well stocked today.
With death staring us in the face, why should we not enjoy what life has to offer?

Fields.MenuText: Until you slip up and get repossessed.
Always ready with an excuse.
Hell with it. Pass the venison.

Fields.DialogueText: Distinction without a difference.
You should see me with an alibi.
I knew you could not resist its siren song!
Remind me how you're paying for all of this?
Impeccable credit.
Oh, come off it. It's not like La Royale is going to bail you out if this rendezvous with your away team doesn't materialize.
And anyway, what's stopping your guys from melting into the Mexican countryside and far away from any Morganas?
Job security.
Job security.
It's not like they can take their debts with them.
C'est vrai, my crew could easily cash out and live like kings in the Mexican underworld.
But the money will not last forever. The thrill of the heist shines all the brighter the further you leave it behind... casting shadows that stir the imagination.
That is what I love most about you humans, Capitaine. Only think of our mad bomber, or anyone else who might fancy a throne in Hell with Morgana bells to herald their reign.
Ambition once aroused is not so easily satisfied. And where better to satisfy it than aboard me?
That's quite a fancy and self-possessed way of saying you screen the crew for greed.
Not all are blessed with it. But I find that those who are respect anyone who can teach them to climb the ladder, so to speak.
I have never yet been wrong, Capitaine. If ever I am... well, we shall get there when we get there.
We'll see about that once we get off this Caribbean detail. If there's anyone missing from the away team when we hit the rendezvous, you owe me.
Not to mention someone who keeps their money in one of her many vaults.
Call it a prospectus.
Do not forget who keeps you from the clutches of these Morganas. If anyone owes anyone anything, mon ami, it is you.
@BATTLE
You're damned lucky as is that Command doesn't believe you were involved in the weapons deal.
Such a dutiful marin you are! Take this for your trouble.
Right where you said it would be, Miss.
Happy to be of service!
Hmm... oui, as expected.
Now, then... as for you, I have an assignment of the utmost import. There is a reward in it for you.
A *very* special reward.
Throw this overboard when the Morganas make their move.
Anything!
A... message in a bottle? Wait... there's a diamond in it!
For a greater purpose than your own greed. Call it playing pirate.
Y... yes, ma'am!

Fields.MenuText: I'm afraid to ask.
Scamming the crew again?
"Playing pirate?"

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, Capitaine, that is the quickest way to becoming an unwitting accomplice.
Non, non, I am no longer that desperate.
There is nothing scandalous about it, Capitaine.
Well, I've done all I can do on my end, but Command's standing firm. They're implementing some of the stricter military mail censorship in our area of operation.
More armed guards for the post. Money, money, money, money, money...
I'd prefer not to be an accomplice at all.
Perhaps, but I like you this way.
Everything about you is scandalous.
My, you do know how to give a compliment.
Manifestement. Until they can justify an armed guard in every telegraph office in every port, my communication with my away team remains unchallenged.
You've already planned for this.
The price of liberty is eternal vigilance, eh?
Liberty has limits. Constraints drive creativity.
Unfortunately for our bomber, they have plumbed the limits of their liberty *and* creativity. He was only too happy to agree to a rendezvous.
With what weaponry? You haven't stolen anything.
I shall persuade the local port authority to report missing a shipment of shells. You shall let Command know all is as planned.
@BATTLE
There's a Morgana group making a play. Ought to be as believable a story as the last time.
Is a year into the war really the time to ask such a question?
Are you going to make a habit of breaking into my quarters?
Oh, of *course.* How *utterly* silly of me. Can't break into your own compartment anyway, I suppose.
Oh, but you can. One must practice somewhere.
Looks like you're practicing your penmanship right now.
I have a year's worth of budgets and journal entries to backdate, Capitaine. Care to join me?

Fields.MenuText: Why the hell would you do that?
I have enough work on my plate without... whatever this is.
Why not. This'll go quicker with two of us.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, this is hardly the strangest project a Belle has ever embarked upon.
Perfectly understandable. This task is best left to someone who does not sleep.
Just make sure the numbers add up.
So what's the project?
My confession.
... Your what?
Our mad bomber has sent me on a search for the soul, Capitaine.
So disgusted were they with the human race and the world they have built that they would claim to throw in with the Morganas.
And even if that is the lie I believe it is, they consider it safer than going legitimate.
But this is only one faithless human. There will be others... unless we show them mercy. Unless we prove to the world that not even the wretched of the earth are beyond saving.
And that starts with me confessing to my own role in this world's wretchedness.
Qu'est-ce que tu penses? Too mawkish?
No, I think they'll buy it. But... why?
I sincerely believed that the shipment was bound for Veracruz, Capitaine. I was willing to spirit them there through unofficial channels. All this our bomber included in his letter.
But he cannot answer for my motive. And who among us has not thought there must be a more expeditious way to arm the people against the Morgana threat?
Naturally, you'll need the documentation to support your selfless skirting of the law.
For a lie to be less dangerous than the truth, it must sometimes be more difficult to tell.
Well, I'd love to be an accessory to the crime, but...
Alas, a lower duty calls.
@BATTLE
This is the place. Now we wait for our bomber to take our contraband weaponry.
The contraband that doesn't exist.
This is the place?
I am not going to tell them, Capitaine. Are you? Will Command?

Fields.MenuText: Set a liar to catch a liar.
If the price is right.
I think I've come too far.

Fields.DialogueText: So pragmatic! That is why you are the capitaine.
Ah, but Capitaine, there is never just one price.
And the only way out is through!
Well, let's get this over with. I don't like staying in one place in this day and age.
Nor I, Capitaine. Nor I.
The rest of the fleet's in position when we're ready. Is that our contact?
In exactly the craft I described.
Wait, Surcouf, it's a--
*BOOM*
Damn it! I thought this was a safe zone!
Didn't we all.
@BATTLE
How can you toast at a time like this?
How can I not? We have solved our immediate problem, have we not?
Santé!
All we did is bait someone into a Morgana ambush. I don't call that a solution.
It put the lie to his collaboration boast once and for all.
A lie much more dangerous than the truth, as it happens. That is what really killed him.
And what about yours?
What about mine?
Running guns to Veracruz? You did it for profit, not peace.
Each of us fights for what they lack most, Capitaine.
Sometimes we find ourselves fighting on the same side.
Command's still going to have plenty of questions about your little "charity drive."
Nothing is a lie if you believe it, Capitaine. And I believe in myself.
I am certain I shall survive this confinement, Capitaine.
Don't be so dramatic. We're restricted to Jamaican waters until Command can verify your story.
Hanging in there?
I wish them happy reading! They will be thrilled by our valiant tales of adventure and derring-do... between card games and dance contests, naturellement.
Perfectly anodyne.
Idyllic. One almost forgets the moonshine explosion.
Oh, that I left in. It would be unbelievable without the occasional indiscretion.

Fields.MenuText: You'd better have a big payday coming.
How in the world did you train them?
Must you drag everyone into your schemes?

Fields.DialogueText: Speaking of things indiscreet, isn't Command going to be suspicious of your missing away team?
Why, Capitaine, they are right here with us.
The locals in our spare uniforms play their parts well, at any rate.
Big enough.
There is a reason I send the less senior crew on my more interesting missions.
Grand ambitions require a grand cast.
Hopefully things can get back to normal once we have Command's okay.
I do not mind a bit of waiting if I know what I am waiting for. It is the only reason I tolerate your human schedules.
You're that confident you'll be able to emancipate yourself?
You want it as much as I do, Capitaine.
A mysterious submarine spirit, free to glide beneath the sea as she pleases... does the prospect not excite you? Like nursing a dolphin to health and setting it frolicking amongst the waves?
Heh. I know what I'd rather have on my side in a Morgana fight.
To choose your allies is very well. To choose your enemies, even better.
How's that?
Had the question of why Avarice so obligingly appeared to solve our blackmail problem not crossed your mind?
@BATTLE
Surcouf, oui.
... Surcouf, no.
The diamond in the message in a bottle was the key. Avarice was drawn to it like a haughty moth.

Fields.MenuText: You keep... emergency diamonds? To lure Avarice?

Fields.DialogueText: Dear Capitaine, I would not have you any other way.
You tipped off the Morganas?

Fields.MenuText: This crosses a line.
Do you have any idea how much trouble this could land us in?

Fields.DialogueText: No. This can't continue.
You don't want to know what I use for Sin.
If you do not have to do something yourself, do not. It matters little who.
Now there is a question I thought you'd never dredge up.
And in the meantime the salvage will come. My creditors' thirst for gold will be slaked. And I will ply these oceans a free Belle, Capitaine. Mark my words.
You'd better believe I am.
According to whom?
Command. Me. Common decency. You're aiding and abetting the enemy.
To clean up our messes, Capitaine. It is they who are aiding and abetting us.
So what happens if someone gets wind of your activities? You'll just set the Morganas on them too?
You humans engage in all sorts of marriages of convenience, Capitaine. My dalliance pales in comparison to the war you've put on hold.
What will you do? Stop fighting this one?
At what cost?
Or accept the wine I pour you, the battles I win for you, and the occasional adventures you bring to such gallant conclusions?
Anything short of my life.
And mine? The crew's?
Our lives.
